Subject: Re: [neat] Is a level of abstraction missing in evolutionary
 computing, particularly relating to neuroevolution and multitasking?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=561746680; y=j4_YiETmRXwdb8DYHmhI3YI730XOBMoVx6bU5kgE_O6OTAO5geg
X-Yahoo-Profile: lordalveric

------=_Part_1308790_589613188.1435500306092
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The current extension to RubyNEAT that I am currently working on allows for=
 modular composition, where each module has its own genotype. The idea here=
 is to be able to compose hand-crafted modular networks of NEAT, ES HyperNE=
AT, and other evolvable neural nets I or anyone might care to add in the fu=
ture.
It is not ready yet, so perhaps I should not be talking about it now.=
 I am also putting into place a queuing mechanism -- RabbitMQ -- so that th=
e phenotypes and their evaluation can be partially rendered and evaluated b=
y "worker nodes" in a language-agnostic manner, allowing for massive scalab=
ility that would not be possible otherwise.
My approaches here are aggressi=
ve, so I cannot put a timeframe for availability on this. But I am always o=
pen to valuable input. =C2=A0=C2=A0
Kind Regards,

Fred Mitchell,=C2=A0


+=
49 (0)15 259 409475, Skype: flajann
 


     On Thursday, 25 June 2015, 8:4=
4, "jonurena@... [neat]" <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
   

 =C2=A0   =
We evolve populations of chromosomes, each of them representing a whole org=
anism, whether the genotype maps 1-to-1 to a phenotype or it maps indirectl=
y, as when dealing with substrates in HyperNEAT. I am building up to relati=
vely recent articles on task transfer and in general AI that would allow me=
 to, hopefully sooner than later, program AI entities for strategy games th=
at can make complex decisions from influence maps, Birds-Eye-View maps, etc=
. I'm guessing it will take neural networks linking to other neural network=
s, with an a priori very hard to deal issue of what outputs of one neural n=
etwork should link to what inputs of others, if and when.=C2=A0I've read on=
 modular networks, but they are still single networks, the phenotype of a s=
ingle genotype.
Reading about how nature deals with it, I come across infor=
mation such as this:=C2=A0

"In eucaryotes, the DNA in the nucleus is divid=
ed between a set of different chromosomes. For example, the human genome=E2=
=80=94approximately 3.2 =C3=97 109 nucleotides=E2=80=94is distributed over =
24 different chromosomes [...]=C2=A0=C2=A0chromosomes are also associated w=
ith many proteins required for the processes of gene expression, DNA replic=
ation, and DNA repair."
So, unless I'm mistaken, nature evolves a "collecti=
on" of chromosomes that each map to different, collaborating phenotypes, or=
 traits, or behaviors. I think I'm not using the term phenotype correctly; =
maybe it would be more accurate to call each mapped chromosome a trait, and=
 the collection of traits a phenotype, but I'll keep referring to the colle=
ctive expression of behavior as the phenotype. We evolve a chromosome that =
maps to a single phenotype. Why aren't we evolving a population of arrays o=
f chromosomes, that during crossover and mutation each crosses over with th=
e chromosome of another individual that is in the same index of the array? =
Shouldn't it be possible to evolve then in the same individual a chromosome=
 that maps, for example, to the physical properties of the organism (such a=
s mass, height, etc., or a single evolved image), in another chromosome of =
the array another network, say a CPPN that would eventually, throught subst=
rate evolution, read from a birds-eye-view map and produce outputs; and in =
another chromosome, a network dedicated to linking other networks other chr=
omosomes produced? So, during the process of genotype to phenotype conversi=
on, each chromosome in the array representing an individual would produce i=
ts own network, whether it maps one-to-one or it evolves the substrate as i=
n ES-HyperNEAT. During fitness evaluation, the brain of each organism consi=
sts of the linked networks, I'm guessing according to a predetermined logic=
 of which should link with which.
Although I'm someone who is into evolutio=
nary computing for fun and to fulfill my curiosity, not a scholar of any ki=
nd, so I'm not particularly to be trusted about what should or shouldn't be=
 done in this field, the above is making quite a lot of sense to me. Does a=
ny of you know if there's work done in this aspect? Has this been tried in =
the past and abandoned? I know we shouldn't follow nature too closely; maxi=
mizing the production of innovation, which is constrained in natural evolut=
ion, is something we can improve in evolutionary computing as the brilliant=
 work on novelty search suggests. But maybe this is an abstraction that cou=
ld benefit the work we are doing.=C2=A0  #yiv6436598766 #yiv6436598766 -- #=

ole organism, whether the genotype maps 1-to-1 to a phenotype or it maps in=
directly, as when dealing with substrates in HyperNEAT. I am building up to=
 relatively recent articles on task transfer and in general AI that would a=

ames that can make complex decisions from influence maps, Birds-Eye-View ma=

n><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;">I've read on modular networks, but t=
hey are still single networks, the phenotype of a single genotype.</span></=
div><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;"><br clear=3D"none"></span></d=
iv><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;">Reading about how nature deals=
 with it, I come across information such as this: <br clear=3D"none"><=
br clear=3D"none">"In eucaryotes, the DNA in the nucleus is divided between=
 a set of different chromosomes. For example, the human genome=E2=80=94appr=
oximately 3.2 =C3=97 109 nucleotides=E2=80=94is distributed over 24 differe=
nt chromosomes [...]  chromosomes are also associated with many p=
roteins required for the processes of gene expression, DNA replication, and=
 DNA repair."</span></div><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;"><br cle=
ar=3D"none"></span></div><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;">So, unle=
ss I'm mistaken, nature evolves a "collection" of chromosomes that each map=
 to different, collaborating phenotypes, or traits, or behaviors. I think I=
'm not using the term phenotype correctly; maybe it would be more accurate =
to call each mapped chromosome a trait, and the collection of traits a phen=
otype, but I'll keep referring to the collective expression of behavior as =
the phenotype. We evolve a chromosome that maps to a single phenotype. Why =
aren't we evolving a population of arrays of chromosomes, that during cross=
over and mutation each crosses over with the chromosome of another individu=
al that is in the same index of the array? Shouldn't it be possible to evol=
ve then in the same individual a chromosome that maps, for example, to the =
physical properties of the organism (such as mass, height, etc., or a singl=
e evolved image), in another chromosome of the array another network, say a=
 CPPN that would eventually, throught substrate evolution, read from a bird=
s-eye-view map and produce outputs; and in another chromosome, a network de=
dicated to linking other networks other chromosomes produced? So, during th=
e process of genotype to phenotype conversion, each chromosome in the array=
 representing an individual would produce its own network, whether it maps =
one-to-one or it evolves the substrate as in ES-HyperNEAT. During fitness e=
valuation, the brain of each organism consists of the linked networks, I'm =
guessing according to a predetermined logic of which should link with which=
.</span></div><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;"><br clear=3D"none">=
</span></div><div><span style=3D"word-spacing:normal;">Although I'm someone=
 who is into evolutionary computing for fun and to fulfill my curiosity, no=
t a scholar of any kind, so I'm not particularly to be trusted about what s=
hould or shouldn't be done in this field, the above is making quite a lot o=
f sense to me. Does any of you know if there's work done in this aspect? Ha=
s this been tried in the past and abandoned? I know we shouldn't follow nat=
ure too closely; maximizing the production of innovation, which is constrai=
ned in natural evolution, is something we can improve in evolutionary compu=
ting as the brilliant work on novelty search suggests. But maybe this is an=
 abstraction that could benefit the work we are doing.</span></div><div><sp=
an style=3D"word-spacing:normal;"> </span></div>

    </div>
